`,(0,e.jsxs)("div",{class:"image-flex",children:[(0,e.jsx)("img",{src:"/static/images/2026/orion-o6n/ha.webp",alt:"llamacpp"}),(0,e.jsx)("img",{src:"/static/images/2026/orion-o6n/ha-voice.webp",alt:"llamacpp"})]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.hr,{}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.h2,{id:"mainline-linux-support-is-still-in-progress",children:[(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{"aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",href:"#mainline-linux-support-is-still-in-progress",children:(0,e.jsx)(n.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"Mainline Linux support is still in progress"]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"Right now, mainline Linux support still isn\u2019t fully complete, and it\u2019s been in progress for close to a year since the Orion O6 release."}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["There is a ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://github.com/Sky1-Linux/linux-sky1",children:(0,e.jsx)(n.strong,{children:"linux-sky"})})," repository that provides patches intended for Linux ",(0,e.jsx)(n.strong,{children:"6.18"}),", so you can build a patched kernel yourself. I tried that approach on the O6N, but I couldn\u2019t get it working properly on this board yet."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["So at the moment, if you want the best experience\u2014especially around things like GPU acceleration\u2014",(0,e.jsx)(n.strong,{children:"Radxa OS is the safer choice"}),"."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.hr,{}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.h2,{id:"where-i-land-on-the-orion-o6n-right-now",children:[(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{"aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",href:"#where-i-land-on-the-orion-o6n-right-now",children:(0,e.jsx)(n.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"Where I land on the Orion O6N right now"]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"At this stage, the software side is still evolving\u2014especially if you want the full experience of the inbuilt GPU and the NPU across different distros."}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"But even with that caveat, this board is already very usable because:"}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.ul,{children:[`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.li,{children:[(0,e.jsx)(n.strong,{children:"UEFI + ACPI"})," make OS installation and booting feel much more \u201CPC-like\u201D"]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.li,{children:["The ",(0,e.jsx)(n.strong,{children:"12-core CPU"})," is excellent for compute-heavy workloads"]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.li,{children:"Storage and I/O are genuinely strong (dual Gen4 x4 NVMe, fast USB, 2.5GbE)"}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.li,{children:"Thermals and power draw are efficient for what it delivers"}),`
`]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["Right now I see it as a really capable ",(0,e.jsx)(n.strong,{children:"server / lab / compute box"}),", especially if you want to run serious workloads on Arm hardware that starts to feel comparable to modern desktop-class CPUs in day-to-day usage."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)("div",{class:"image-flex",children:(0,e.jsx)("img",{src:"/static/images/2026/orion-o6n/o6n-fan.webp",alt:"o6n-fan"})}),`

;return Component;

toc.value: OS support: UEFI makes it so much easier
GPU testing: Vulkan vs OpenGL results
Power and thermals: efficient, cool, and silent
AI and LLM tests on CPU
Networking: 2.5GbE is solid, Wi-Fi works (after firmware)
Home Assistant + local voice: surprisingly quick
Mainline Linux support is still in progress
Where I land on the Orion O6N right now

frontMatter.title: Radxa Orion O6N: My experience with this Nano-ITX Arm powerhouse
frontMatter.author: Amrut Prabhu
frontMatter.summary: My Radxa Dragon Q6A review with benchmark results, thermals, NVMe/UFS speeds, Home Assistant voice tests, and a walkthrough of Windows 11 on ARM (UEFI).

suggestedArticles.title: Radxa Cubie A7A Review: Pi-Sized Power With PCIe, NVMe, USB 3.1 Gen2
Radxa Cubie A5E Hands-On: The Budget NVMe SBC
I Built A DIY 10 Inch Server Rack

specifications.CPU:
12-core tri-cluster:
4× Cortex-A720 (big) up to 2.6GHz
4× Cortex-A720 (mid) up to 2.4GHz
4× Cortex-A520 (LITTLE) up to 1.8GHz
12MB shared L3 cache

GPU.Support:
Vulkan 1.4
OpenGL ES 4.3
OpenCL 3.0
Hardware ray tracing

specifications.AI Capabilities:
NPU: 30 TOPS
Precision: INT4 / INT8 / INT16, FP16, TF32
specifications.Storage:
2× M.2 M-Key NVMe SSD slots (PCIe Gen4 x4 per slot)
1× UFS module connector (Radxa UFS module)
specifications.Video Output:
1× DisplayPort 1.4 (up to 4K@120Hz, MST supported)
1× HDMI 2.0 (up to 4K@60Hz)
1× USB-C (USB 3.2 Gen2 + DisplayPort Alt Mode, up to 4K@60Hz)

Network.Cellular: Optional via M.2 B-Key + Nano SIM slot

specifications.USB:
1× USB-C (USB 3.2 Gen2 10Gbps + DP Alt Mode)
2× USB-A (USB 3.2 Gen2 10Gbps)
3× USB-A (USB 2.0)
specifications.Power:
12V DC via 5.5×2.5mm (5525) barrel jack
12V via 4-pin power connector.
specifications.Audio: No dedicated 3.5mm audio jack (audio via HDMI/DP)
specifications.Camera:
2× MIPI CSI camera connectors
4-lane or 2-lane per port
specifications.Cooling:
4-pin CPU fan header with PWM control + TACH feedback
75×75mm heatsink mounting holes
specifications.Expansion:
1× M.2 E-Key (PCIe Gen4 x2 + USB) for wireless modules
1× M.2 B-Key (USB) for cellular modules
40-pin GPIO header (onboard)
specifications.Operating System:
Debian 
Ubuntu
Fedora Linux
Radxa OS
